text: To say the least...

elements.text: To say the least...

text: "By keeping Dynamicland so proprietary and under wraps..." I don't think that it is proprietary. A different approach at naming this could be: *Bret is trying to build a different computing culture*

elements.text: "By keeping Dynamicland so proprietary and under wraps..." I don't think that it is proprietary. A different approach at naming this could be:

text: I would argue that most programmers  are not aware of the "normal" of their programming culture. As most people are not aware of the "normal" of their  overall culture...

elements.text: I would argue that most programmers  are not aware of the "normal" of their programming culture. As most people are not aware of the "normal" of their  overall culture...

text: Seymour Papert is stated as the father (or strong influencer) of maker spaces.  But the majority of programming does not happen in maker spaces or communal spaces. It even doesn't happen in lets say "science" spaces as bret mentions.

elements.text: Seymour Papert is stated as the father (or strong influencer) of maker spaces.  But the majority of programming does not happen in maker spaces or communal spaces. It even doesn't happen in lets say "science" spaces as bret mentions.

text: Most of programming is happening in _*Industry .*_ That is there  is a nation state which inhibits a education system which produces people who work for corporations to write code, lots of code.

elements.text: Most of programming is happening in
Industry .
That is there  is a nation state which inhibits a education system which produces people who work for corporations to write code, lots of code.

text: The most used programming languages are the ones used in industry: javascript , java, c, c++, python

elements.text: The most used programming languages are the ones used in industry: javascript , java, c, c++, python

text: Git is a versioning system. GitHub was a Hosting Service to share repositories. Through extensive sharing ( open Source culture?) patterns of behaviour emerged ( merge /pull request, issues, crowdfunding ...)

elements.text: Git is a versioning system. GitHub was a Hosting Service to share repositories. Through extensive sharing ( open Source culture?) patterns of behaviour emerged ( merge /pull request, issues, crowdfunding ...)

text: I used a lot of words to describe this and its still very sketchy but if bret tries to change or introduce that kind of novel culture it will take a very long time

elements.text: I used a lot of words to describe this and its still very sketchy but if bret tries to change or introduce that kind of novel culture it will take a very long time

text: And it will only succeed if its really sustainable. Meaning if people are starting to gather around these kinds of ideas for more then 1 month, 1 year or one mans life time.

elements.text: And it will only succeed if its really sustainable. Meaning if people are starting to gather around these kinds of ideas for more then 1 month, 1 year or one mans life time.

text: Its interesting to see how bret tries to detach himself from "Industry" while the hardware he uses very much is a product of industry.

elements.text: Its interesting to see how bret tries to detach himself from "Industry" while the hardware he uses very much is a product of industry.

text: I do not see dynamic land - yet? - as a sustainable project but time will tell.

elements.text: I do not see dynamic land - yet? - as a sustainable project but time will tell.

text: In some sense I feel bret is wishing for a kind of library economy: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?app=desktop&v=NOYa3YzVtyk>

elements.text: In some sense I feel bret is wishing for a kind of library economy:

text: yes very interesting one, I think I found it through steve klabnik at one point.

elements.text: yes very interesting one, I think I found it through steve klabnik at one point.

text: I found the book "software takes over" through it.

elements.text: I found the book "software takes over" through it.

text: When I visited Dynamicland for the first time, I was disappointed. It was extremely low-tech and not at all shiny and polished as his demos were. As Bret was explaining things, you could also implicitly hear how he considers everything technological as completely replaceable, almost to the point where it sounded like it’s not important at all. It took me a while to understand, but then it clicked: It was never about the technology. It was always about the culture.

elements.text: When I visited Dynamicland for the first time, I was disappointed. It was extremely low-tech and not at all shiny and polished as his demos were. As Bret was explaining things, you could also implicitly hear how he considers everything technological as completely replaceable, almost to the point where it sounded like it’s not important at all. It took me a while to understand, but then it clicked: It was never about the technology. It was always about the culture.

text:
Train Jam to Strange Loop
A handful of folks from this community and adjacent spaces are riding a train from Seattle to St. Louis, arriving the night before Strange Loop. Come along to spend some time away from the daily routine, see the continental US, and hack / hang with other hack-hangers.

Register: <https://lu.ma/trainjam2023|https://lu.ma/trainjam2023>
Info: <https://talk.fission.codes/t/trainjam-2023/4789|https://talk.fission.codes/t/trainjam-2023/4789>

elements.text:
Train Jam to Strange Loop
A handful of folks from this community and adjacent spaces are riding a train from Seattle to St. Louis, arriving the night before Strange Loop
Come along to spend some time away from the daily routine, see the continental US, and hack / hang with other hack-hangers
Register:
https://lu.ma/trainjam2023
Info:
https://talk.fission.codes/t/trainjam-2023/4789

text:
I'm undecided — it'd be fun, but I also had plans to be in St. Louis for these two days, which would be annoying to cancel. So depending how my day goes today and what whims I choose to follow, I may or may not be on the train.

<@UCUSW7WVD> and <@U013ZLJARC7> have booked tickets, so presumably you'll see them if you choose to go.

text:
And — sold out!

Also, I decided to sit this one out. But if anyone is in St. Louis a day or two before the conf, I'll be looking to meet folks, hang out, and probably eat as much pizza as I can. Plan accordingly!
